3.12.text: and today we've come to Live Lab to dissect some lungs.

7.25.text:
So our lungs can be found just behind
our ribs inside our chest,

12.45.text:
and they're responsible for exchanging
the gases between the air

15.91.text:
and our bodies: getting rid of the carbon
dioxide we don't need

19.18.text: and taking in the oxygen that we do.

22.00.text: That oxygen is carried around by the blood in our bodies,

24.79.text:
which needs to be pumped by the heart,
and we can find that

28.00.text: just behind lungs. So when you breathe in

31.97.text:
the air passes through your nose and mouth,
arriving at your throat;

35.88.text: Where you can find this thing here, this

38.95.text: is called the voice box or larynx.

42.48.text:
And attached, we can find two tubes heading down from it.
This one here

46.98.text:
goes down towards the lungs - this is
called the windpipe or 'trachea' -

53.56.text: oesophagus. You want your air go

56.69.text:
down the trachea to your lungs and your
food to go

60.18.text:
through the oesophagus. This is called an
epiglottis

63.86.text: when you swallow it closes over the top,

68.59.text: blocking the trachea, preventing any food from going down and so instead

72.65.text: your food just passes in to the oesophagus.

77.27.text: So now we're going to remove the voicebox.

85.25.text:
we can see a structure which pinches
together

89.16.text: and those are the vocal cords.

92.75.text:
Now, whenever you want to make a sound
all you need to do

95.94.text:
is just vibrate them; and you can feel this
for yourself by

99.61.text:
placing your hand down your throat I'm
going "Aaaahhhhh".

103.64.text:
Combined with your lips and your
tongue that

110.90.text:
So the air passes down the
trachea towards the lungs, and what we can see here

115.93.text:
are some rings of cartilage. So these rings
of cartilage help to keep the windpipe

121.30.text:
open, giving the air a clear passage going
down to the lungs.

124.66.text:
But, if you know anyone who suffers from
Asthma,

127.83.text:
these rings of cartilage can collapse down,
preventing the air

131.91.text: from getting a clear passage down.

135.10.text:
But, if you take an inhaler and breathe in that
medicine, they will open back up

138.92.text:
meaning they can breathe properly once
again. So let's cut down the trachea,

147.04.text: Inside here we can see this white foamy stuff,

154.02.text:
You have mucus in your lungs too, and it
helps to prevent

157.96.text:
any bits and dust and bacteria from getting in
to the lungs.

161.11.text:
So when we get to the bottom of the trachea,
we can see that it branches off

165.45.text:
to two tubes called a 'bronchus'. So the
air passes

169.71.text: down here going into the lungs.

173.35.text:
So let's cut down one of these tubes. Just like
the branches of a tree,

178.52.text:
these branches gets smaller and smaller
becoming bronchi

182.33.text:
and then the smallest ones are called
bronchioles.

185.36.text:
And right at the end of these bronchioles are
microscopic structures called

190.52.text: 'air-sacs' or 'alveloi', and the alveoli is the place

194.29.text:
where the gases exchange between your
body and the air.

197.92.text:
Now we can't see these alveoli, but if
we cut off

202.07.text: part of the lungs, and drop it into some water,

205.90.text:
then we should be able to see what's
inside it.

216.24.text:
So we can see the lung floats on the
surface of the water because of the air

220.39.text:
but if we compare this to a bit if the
diaphragm...

223.44.text:
without that air in it, the muscle is far more
dense,

226.95.text: so it sinks. So what actually happens

230.14.text: to the lungs when it inflates? Well to show you guys this, I have a syringe

234.66.text: full of air, and I'm going to place this into the top

238.39.text: of one of those bronchial tubes, and if I

247.38.text: we can see the lungs inflate.

254.80.text:
For more insides on
the outside, check out our dissections playlist.
